ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Growth of ears reconstructed from autologous rib cartilage

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery

AbstractSection.Heading: Background
AbstractSection.Para: Microtia is a congenital abnormality characterised by a deformed or absent auricle, which can be reconstructed surgically using autologous rib cartilage. Long-term symmetry in size is an important goal. The optimal age for surgery and sizing of the framework is still under debate, as it has not been clearly shown if the reconstructed ear grows. Our objective was to determine if the reconstructed ear grows and to compare the growth with the normal ear.

AbstractSection.Heading: Methods
AbstractSection.Para: Twenty-two patients were selected in this retrospective study. Digital morphometry was used to measure the length of the reconstructed and normal ears. An initial photograph had been taken after the reconstruction at a median of 11.2 years (range 8.0–12.5 years) of age and a second photograph at a median of 16.3 years (range 14.5–21.6 years). The median follow-up time was 5.6 years (range 2.1–10.6 years). The differences in length in the first and second photograph were calculated, and paired Student’s t tests and Mann–Whitney U tests were used for the analysis.

AbstractSection.Heading: Results
AbstractSection.Para: The mean growth of the reconstructed ears was 0.62 cm (95 % CI 0.43–0.81) and that of the normal ears was 0.53 cm (95 % CI 0.38–0.68). There was no significant difference between the growth of the normal and the reconstructed ears (p = 0.26).

AbstractSection.Heading: Conclusions
AbstractSection.Para: The reconstructed ears grew during the studied time-interval, and this was most likely due to growth of the actual cartilage. There was no significant difference between the growth on the reconstructed and normal sides.
Level of evidence: Level III, risk/prognostic study.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Microtia is a congenital abnormality characterised by a deformed or absent auricle, which is unilateral in about 90 % of cases [1]. Microtia is often associated with hemifacial microsomia, which can be seen as a spectrum of malformations where an isolated microtia would be a mild form [2]. The prevalence in Sweden is 2.35 per 10,000 births [3]. The microtia classification system used divides the malformation into the concha type, small concha type, lobular type and anotia depending on the appearance of the ear [4].

The ears grow rapidly during the first 3–6 months and then grow slower until adulthood [5]. The age at which the length is mature varies slightly between studies due to, for example, the ethnicity of the study population and the measurement method, but has been estimated to be between 11 and 14 years [5–7].

The deformed ear can be reconstructed surgically by using autologous rib cartilage to create the framework of a new ear. This is a three- to four-stage procedure originally developed by Tanzer [8] and altered by Brent [9, 10]. There is also another technique developed by Nagata where only two sessions are needed [11]. At our unit, we have developed a three-stage technique inspired both by Nagata and Brent. The reconstruction is often initiated at 7 years of age and completed 1.5 years later (Fig. 1).
Fig. 1
Reconstructed ear before (a) and after (b) surgery, and ear on the normal side (c)

Whether the reconstructed ears grow is under debate. Evaluation of eventual growth is important to determine the optimal age for surgery, and to decide if the framework initially should be oversized compared to the normal ear.

The objective of this study was to observe any changes in the size of the reconstructed ear and to compare these with the changes of the normal ear. During puberty, thoracic dimensions greatly expand [12], and it could be anticipated to be the time when the harvested cartilage would grow the most. In this study, analysis of the ear size was performed before and after puberty.

Section1.Heading: Material and methods
Section1.Para: At the time of this study, our registry for auricular reconstruction contained 322 patients. This registry contained all ear reconstructions made at our hospital, with diagnoses including microtia, trauma and ENT tumours. To evaluate the growth of the reconstructed ear, the inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) unilateral microtia, (2) completed reconstruction with postoperative photographic documentation before the age of 12.5 years and (3) a final photograph after the age of 14.5 years.

Twenty-two patients met these limited criteria. Two photographs of the ears of each patient were analysed, the first before the age of 12.5 and the second at 14.5 years or later. All patients with surgical procedures done during the follow-up time were reviewed by a plastic surgeon that specialised in ear reconstructions. Those who had undergone surgery that was judged to significantly alter the length of the ear were excluded. These procedures included alterations of the lobule or helix.

The group was stratified into subgroups depending on whether surgical procedures had been done during the follow-up time, as this could possibly affect the length. The group was also divided by follow-up time of >5 and <5 years.

Seven (32 %) of the 22 included patients had undergone a surgical procedure in the ear region during follow-up. Fourteen (64 %) had a follow-up time of >5 years. See Fig. 2 for attrition analysis.
Fig. 2
Attrition analysis of microtia registry

The median age of the first reconstructive surgery was 7.5 years (range 6.1–10.6 years). The median age for the first photograph was 11.2 years (range 8.0–12.5 years), and 16.3 years (range 14.5–21.6 years) for the second photograph. The median follow-up time was 5.6 years (range 2.1–10.6 years).

Digital morphometry was used for the measurements, which has a high interindividual variation, but an intraindividual random error comparable with the classic methods of calliper or compass and ruler [13]. To assess the accuracy of the examiner, a validation was done where the ears of 10 patients were measured twice, with an interval of 1 week. The means of the two measurements were compared and the standard deviation of the difference between the means calculated. Using these values, random and systematic errors were calculated according to the methods of Bland and Altmann [14].
The length, defined as the longest axis of the ear, was measured bilaterally by a single examiner using Picsara Professional Image Management, ver 8.9 r5 (Euromed Networks AB).

The length of the reconstructed ear and the normal ear were measured in the first and second photographs, respectively. Three subsequent measurements were made for each photograph, and the mean of these was used in the calculations described in the following section.
The chronologic order of the first and second photographs was blinded to the examiner until the measurements were completed.

Section1.Heading: Statistical evaluation
Section1.Para: Paired Student’s t tests were used for comparing the different length measurements. Mann–Whitney U tests were used for the subgroup comparisons, including follow-up time of more or less than 5 years, and whether patients underwent surgical procedure during the follow-up period. All analyses were calculated with SPSS Statistics, version 22, IBM.

Section1.Heading: Results
Section1.Para: In the validation series, the random error of the length measurements was 0.63 mm for the reconstructed ear and 0.79 mm for the normal ear. The systematic error for this method was negligible.

The mean length of the reconstructed ears at the first measurement was 5.46 and 6.09 cm at the second measurement. The mean length of the normal ears was 5.59 cm at the first measurement and 6.12 cm at the second measurement (Table 1).

The difference between the first and second measurement of the reconstructed ear was 0.62 cm (95 % CI 0.43–0.81 cm), an 11 % length increase. The difference between the first and second measurement of the normal ear was 0.53 cm (95 % CI 0.38–0.68 cm), a 9.5 % length increase. The difference between the growth of the reconstructed and normal ears during the studied time-period was 0.10 cm (95 % CI −0.08–0.27), which was insignificant. The distribution of the growth in the study group is shown in Fig. 3.
Fig. 3
Distribution of growth of reconstructed and normal ears (cm)

The mean difference between the normal and reconstructed ears was 0.46 cm at the first measurement and 0.41 cm at the second measurement (Figs. 4 and 5).
Fig. 4
Distribution of the differences between the normal and reconstructed ears at the first measurement (cm). Y-axis shows number of study subjects in each length interval
Fig. 5
Distribution of the differences between the normal and reconstructed ears at the second measurement (cm). Y-axis shows number of study subjects in each length interval

The length of the reconstructed and normal ears had increased significantly more in the group followed for >5 years compared with the group followed for <5 years (p = 0.01 and p = 0.005, respectively). The difference of the age at first surgery between these groups was negligible.
There was no significant difference between the group that underwent a surgical procedure during follow-up time and the group that had not (p = 0.41).

Section1.Heading: Discussion
Section1.Para: Ever since Burt Brent reported his clinical observations of substantial growth of the reconstructed ear at long-term follow-up, the subject of the growth of the cartilage has been under debate.

In this study of cartilage growth, the inclusion criteria were very strict, yielding a small selection of patients with unilateral microtia from a registry for ear reconstruction containing over 300 patients. This strategy gave a small but homogenous group of patients. One of the limitations in the material was adequate photographic documentation—despite the large photo registry, few patients had continuous documentation.

A third of the study group had undergone minor surgical procedures during the follow-up time. There was a theoretical risk that these small procedures could alter the length of the ear. However, the results show that there was no growth difference between the subjects that had undergone a procedure during follow-up time and the subjects that had not. Thus, these patients were not excluded from the study.
The single examiner’s individual random and systematic errors were determined for the method of measurement used in this study. These were small compared to the observed growth.

The first photograph was usually taken at the 1-year follow-up, but for some subjects, this was not possible as they underwent additional minor correctional procedures. This explains the large time-interval between the first surgery and the first photograph in our study group.

There are several possible methods for measuring ears, including magnetic resonance tomography, tantalum beads in the cartilage and computerised tomography. These tests are either expensive or invasive. Callipers or a compass and ruler are widely used but are not reproducible. We used digital morphometry, since this is relatively precise, non-invasive and the measurements can be done and redone retrospectively.

We believe that it is the cartilage framework that grows, which is indirectly shown as an increase in total ear length. It is implausible that the soft tissue, a minor part of the total length, would contribute much to the growth of the ear. Growth due to increased laxity is not normally seen at this age.

Previous studies have reported an increase of 1–5.3 mm in length of the normal ear in the age-span of 11–17 years. Our findings correspond to the upper range of these findings [5–7, 15]. The studies are not completely consistent with each other, which could be due to the different definitions and measurements of ear length. Nor is the material in these studies comparable to ours regarding the age-span. Since our measurements began at a younger age, it could be anticipated that we would find growth of the normal ear within the upper range of previously reported observations. A source of bias could be that knowledge of the first measurement affected the second measurement. This was eliminated in our study by blinding the chronological order of the photos to the examiner. None of the aforementioned studies tested the repeatability of their method and the examiners.
In this retrospective study, the reconstructed ears grew significantly. This is consistent with some earlier studies.

Thomson and Winslow found that compared to lead templates of the normal ear at the time of the first surgery, tracings of both the normal and reconstructed ears had increased in size after a minimum follow-up of 2 years, and that the difference in size between the normal and reconstructed ears was not significant [16]. Instead of measuring the ears directly, templates were used, which is a potential source of error. The parameters used were area and perimeter, which differs from other studies, and makes the results difficult to compare.

DellaCroce et al. measured the reconstructed ears of 10 patients with an average follow-up time of 3 years, and found a length increase of 10.4 % and a width increase of 7.02 %, which was not significantly different from the growth of the normal ear on the six patients with unilateral microtia. The study group had only undergone the first stage of surgery at 5–10 years of age [17]. From our experience, ear width is difficult to measure due to the less defined landmarks.

Kizhner and Barak found that the length decreased by 3.1 % and the width increased by 4.0 % when comparing measurements of the reconstructed ear with the size of the original template in 28 patients operated with the Nagata technique. Only 11 of these underwent the procedure before maturity (stated as 12–13 years of age). The follow-up time varied between 9 and 28 months. The measurements here were also done on templates [18], which creates possible systematic or random errors.

Xu et al. found a width increase of 3.7 and 3.9 % in children and adolescents, respectively, after a mean follow-up time of 2.5 years. Compared with the normal ear, the height decreased by 1.3 % in the children and 2.1 % in the adolescent group. The measurements were done directly on the ear with a calliper. Xu et al. suggested that the relative shrinkage could be due to the patients putting pressure on the ear, thus restricting blood flow to the graft. The 126 patients studied were Asians [19] as opposed to our study group, which was mostly Caucasians.

Possible reasons for the inconsistencies in the results of these studies are use of different methods, study of different age-spans and the longer follow-up time of our study. The comparison we made between the growth of the reconstructed ears of the subjects followed for <5 and >5 years indicates that on average, the ears grow more the longer the follow-up time during the age-span that we studied.

The mean difference in length between the normal ear and the reconstructed ear of each study subject at the time of the first and second photographs, respectively, was small. There was, however, a variance around the mean. At the end of follow-up, 64 % had a difference of <0.5 cm and 91 % <1.0 cm. In comparison, Sforza et al. stated that at the age of 15–17 years, the mean difference between a normal right and left ear is 1.1 mm, but the range of the differences was not clearly stated [15].

We found that the reconstructed ears grew as much as the normal ears, and hence it is reasonable to use the normal ear as a template at the time of the first reconstructive stage. Our results also support commencing the reconstructive series as early as at the age of 7 years.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Ethical standards
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: This study was not considered to be harmful in any way to the study subjects, and all information used was acquired from already existing medical records. For this type of study, formal consent from a local ethics committee is not required.

FormalPara.Heading: Conflict of interest
FormalPara.Para: Emma Roos, Sven-Olof Wikström and Martin Öberg declare that they have no conflict of interest.

FormalPara.Heading: Patient consent
FormalPara.Para: Parents or legal guardians provided written consent for the inclusion of patients and use of their images in this study.
